FacilityName: Smithfield Packaged Meats Corp. - Lincoln, NE

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Smithfield Lincoln is engaged in the production of pork products for human consumption.  The facility is located at 200 South 2nd Street, Lincoln, Nebraska, 68508.  The NAICS code is 311612.  The facility has approximately 500 full time employees and operates 24 hours/day, 7 days/week, 52 weeks/year.



This Plan informs all interested parties that this facility is participating in the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program defined in 29 CFR 1910.119 and the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) defined in 40 CFR Part 68. These programs provide for the implementation of detailed Prevention and response procedures when storing and handling hazardous chemicals. The program objectives are to ensure worker and public safety and to provide environmental protection.

 

Anhydrous ammonia is the only substance at the facility that is regulated under the PSM and RMP programs. This is the same type of ammonia commonly sprayed on fields by farmers to fertilize crops. Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant throughout the plant to maintain desired meat temperatures in coolers, freezers and working areas. Expelling heat caused from altering the ammonia between a liquid and a gas state creates refrigeration in the facility. This refrigeration system consists of a series of compressors, condensers, evaporators, vessels, piping and valves.



The offsite consequences of analysis was determined utilizing RMP*Comp and the population data is based upon information pulled from Marplot on 9/13/2018. How to determine the WCS & ARS was derived from the Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities (May 2004).



The ammonia refrigeration system is operated with a variety of safety devices employed within the system, included are: high and low level automated shutdown systems and high and low pressure automated shutdown systems. Alarm systems are utilized to provide early detection of problems within the system before shutdowns occur.



This faci

lity's emergency response program is an action plan to respond to and resolve incidents associated with the ammonia refrigeration system. The Fire Department / Hazmat Team will be notified so that they can provide assistance during an incident. If it is necessary to contact the public regarding an ammonia release, the local fire department will be contacted to coordinate with the police department. The police department will notify residents and business locations.



This facility had a reportable release September 22, 2015. We had some debris/contamination get into an A4AD valve on the water chiller, causing it not to operate correctly. With this valve not operating correctly the water going across the plates caused the liquid ammonia to boil and change to vapor which expanded and could not relieve through the A4AD and the SRV lifted like it was designed to do. It was discovered very quickly and isolated. However, some debris prevented the SRV from reseating properly so it continued to weep past until we switched the valve over to the other SRV. In lieu of repairing and re-piping the water chiller we have taken it out of service and removed it from the system.  



The facility utilizes Process Hazard Analysis, Compliance Audits, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews, Mechanical Integrity inspections, Preventative Maintenance activity, equipment inspections, and training to ensure mitigation and control of potential incidents.



The facility will make changes to the system and train as necessary to resolve items noted during the Process Hazard Analysis, Compliance Audit, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews, and Mechanical Integrity inspections to improve the safety of the system. Changes will be placed on an action list, evaluated, and implemented in a timely manner.
